mdx: # Icon Button Provides a compact and visually efficient way to represent actions, especially when space is limited or the action is universally understood. ## Overview These specifications define the standard styles and variations for icon buttons within our design system, covering different visual treatments for diverse use cases. ### Resources Deep dive into implementation details and access the Nimbus design library. [Figma library](https://www.figma.com/design/AvtPX6g7OGGCRvNlatGOIY/NIMBUS-design-system?node-id=346-2570&m=dev) ## Hierarchy #### Most common: Ghost Ghost icon buttons are used most often, the represent familiar actions that don't compete with a primary action on the page. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ); }; ``` #### Use sparingly: Solid Solid icon buttons are sparingly used, but represent commonly understood primary actions by the user. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ); }; ``` #### Least used: Outline Outline icon buttons are used as secondary buttons, used often in button groups to represent icon toggles and within data tables. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ); }; ``` ## Variables Get familiar with the features. ### Size #### Medium (40px) These are the default and preferred size for icon buttons. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ); }; ``` #### X-Small (32px) Placed in a small dense content areas, e.g., in pop-over or inside a data table. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ); }; ``` #### XX-Small (24px) 2XS is used sparingly mostly inside other components e.g, inside inputs or filter badges. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ); }; ``` ### Color Palette #### Primary This is the default color palette for the icon button. This styling should be used most commonly for all actions. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ); }; ``` #### Critical Use this icon button when the user is approaching a permanent destructive action. See guidelines for more information. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ); }; ``` #### Tooltip For accessibility compliance (and good user experience for all) icon buttons that do not have a label must have a tooltip. Go to tooltips for more information about the component. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( Edit ); }; ``` ## Guidelines Icon buttons are interactive elements that empower users to trigger actions and navigate within your product. They serve as clear calls to action, guiding users through key flows and enabling them to interact with content in meaningful ways. These guidelines ensure consistent styling and behavior for all buttons, contributing to a cohesive and predictable user experience. ### Writing guidelines - Use [Material Icons](https://mui.com/material-ui/material-icons/?theme=Outlined&query=access#search-material-icons) in outline style before adding a new custom icon. - Use standard icons. - Provide tooltips. - Combine with text when needed. - Be consistent. - Test with users. #### Preferred words | **Example** | **Description** | | ---------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | | Use for "edit". | | | Upload. | | | Download. | | | "Table settings" Shows customizable elements for tables. | | | "More options" shows a list of other features or tools that are not primary or secondary actions. Usually paired with buttons in a button group. For consistency, use the vertical dot version. | | | "Drag" allows a user to drag elements to reorder. | | | Use for "remove". This removes the relationship but does **not** delete this item completely. | | | Use for "delete". This is a destructive action, removes item completely. | #### Avoid these words | **Avoid Icon/Concept** | **Use this instead** | | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------- | | | Use a button with "Save" instead of an icon button. | | | Use the vertical dot version to show more options. | | | If using for the same function as "delete" use consistent icon above. | | | If using for the same function as "upload" use consistent icon above. | | | If using for the same function as "download" use consistent icon above. | ### Usage #### Common & effective placements: - **Toolbars**: Icon buttons are perfect for toolbars due to their compact size. They allow for many actions to be readily available without cluttering the interface. - **Navigation** bars/headers: Often used for actions like search, settings, or menu access. Placement here makes these key functions easily accessible throughout the app. - **Within** lists/grids: Icon buttons can be placed next to list items or grid elements to provide actions specific to that item (e.g., edit, delete, share). - **Contextual** menus: Icon buttons can be used within dropdown menus or context menus to provide a visual representation of available actions. #### Placement considerations: - **Related to content**: Place icon buttons close to the content they affect. For example, an edit button should be near the text it's used to edit. - **Consistency**: Maintain consistent placement of similar icon buttons. Users expect to find common actions in the same place. - **Groupings**: If you have multiple related icon buttons, grouping them together visually. Helps users understand the relationships between the actions. - **Avoid clutter**: Don't overcrowd your UI with too many icon buttons. > [!TIP]\ > When to use - Space is limited. - Actions are universally recognized. - Reinforcing meaning. - Adding visual appeal. - Supporting multiple languages. - Interfaces are simple and consistent. > [!CAUTION]\ > When not to use - Actions are ambiguous. - Context is crucial. - Actions are critical. - Space is plentiful. - Interfaces are complex. - Testing reveals confusion. ### Color palette and style usage Icons that are on the left are the best placement. Icons are used to lead the user to the right action quickly by scanning. Ok ways to break this rule are with drop downs and right pointing arrows. #### Most common: Ghost They are often seen next to tables, fields, and toolbars. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ) } ``` #### Solid and outline Solid icon buttons are most commonly seen in navigation. Outline buttons are most commonly seen in groups of two representing views that can be toggled. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ) } ``` #### Critical color palette Reserved for destructive actions, such as deleting something or removing a connection. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ) } ``` ### Icon placement The ideal placement of an icon button depends heavily on its function and the overall UI design. Think about the button's function, the content it relates to, and how users will expect to find it. Consistency and user testing are key to optimizing icon button placement. > [!TIP]\ > **Do** > > - Tools are grouped together, and adhere to current common page pattern > design. > [!CAUTION]\ > **Don't** > > - Navigation is higher hierarchy than icon button tools, this is not a common > pattern. ### Button groupings Button groups are UI elements that organize multiple buttons together, often visually as a single unit. They serve to present users with a set of related choices or actions in a compact and organized way. > [!TIP]\ > **Do** > > - If you use a stack of icon buttons for actions, use max 4 and hide the rest > within a "more" icon. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ) } ``` > [!CAUTION]\ > **Don't** > > - Avoid having all the options as solid primary filled buttons. > - Try not to have icon buttons sandwiched between buttons. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ) } ``` > [!TIP]\ > **Do** > > - When offering a toggle experience, connect these icon buttons > - Include a tooltip explaining the options. > - Selected option is using the "Solid" state. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ) } ``` > [!CAUTION]\ > **Don't** > > - If offering a toggle like option view, do not show options as separate > - Does not include tooltips or labels, makes it confusing to users to > understand this is a either/or choice. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ) } ``` > [!TIP]\ > **Do** > > - When pairing icon buttons together, use the ghost style. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ) } ``` > [!CAUTION]\ > **Don't** > > - Avoid having two primary solid icon buttons in the same area. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( ) } ``` ### Tooltips Make sure to place tooltips in areas where they will be seen easily. > [!TIP]\ > **Do** > > - Place tooltips so that it makes information easy to read. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( Table settings Product columns Variant columns Layout settings ) } ``` > [!CAUTION]\ > **Don't** > > - Be aware of overlap of element placements. > - Place tooltips so that it makes information easy to read. > - Don't use tooltips to cover the icon button. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( Table settings Product columns Variant columns Layout settings Table settings ) } ``` ## Properties ## Accessibility The component uses `onPress*` props to handle all user interactions—mouse clicks, touch taps, and keyboard presses—consistently. These props (`onPress`, `onPressStart`, `onPressEnd`, etc.) ensure a smooth and accessible experience regardless of the user's input method or device. ```jsx-live const App = () => { return ( alert('Button pressed!')}> ) } ``` ### Accessibility standards #### 1. Perceivable: - **Sufficient Color Contrast:** Ensure enough contrast between the icon and its background. WCAG requires a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 for graphical elements and 4.5:1 for text. Tools like WebAIM's color contrast checker can help you verify this. - **Non-text Content:** Icons are considered non-text content. WCAG requires that all non-text content has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose. This usually means providing an alternative text (alt text) for the icon. - **Visual Cues:** Don't rely solely on color to convey information. Use additional visual cues like shapes, patterns, or text labels to ensure that the icon's meaning is clear to everyone, including people with color blindness. #### 2. Operable: - **Keyboard Accessibility:** Icon buttons must be operable using a keyboard. Users should be able to navigate to the button using the Tab key and activate it using the Enter or Space key. - **Target Size:** Ensure that the icon button is large enough to be easily clickable, especially on touchscreens. WCAG recommends a minimum target size of 24x24 CSS pixels. - **Focus Indicator:** Provide a clear visual indicator when the icon button receives keyboard focus. This helps users understand which element is currently active. #### 3. Understandable: - **Clear Labels:** If the icon's meaning isn't universally understood, provide a text label or tooltip to clarify its purpose. This is especially important for less common icons. - **Consistent Design:** Use icons consistently throughout your website. This helps users learn the meaning of each icon and makes it easier for them to navigate your site. #### 4. Robust: - **Assistive Technology Compatibility:** Ensure that icon buttons are compatible with assistive technologies like screen readers. This often involves using proper HTML markup and ARIA attributes to provide semantic information about the button.
